title: Pakistan Blinked. The India Match Is On.
summary: After a 10-day boycott standoff, Pakistan agreed to play India at the T20 World Cup.
content:
For ten days, Pakistan refused to play India.

The T20 World Cup **Group A fixture** — the most watched cricket match on earth — was in doubt.

Pakistan said they were boycotting **in solidarity with Bangladesh.** The political context: tensions between India and Bangladesh had been escalating for months.

## 10 | Days of deadlock before Pakistan backed down

The ICC was caught between two nuclear powers arguing through sport. Negotiations ran around the clock.

>> "The standoff ended in an evening of frenzied diplomacy." — The Athletic

Then Pakistan blinked.

They agreed to play. The reasons weren't explained with clarity. But cricket's economics are merciless — **India vs Pakistan generates more revenue than entire tournament rounds.**

The match is back on. The boycott is over. The politics aren't.

This wasn't really about cricket. It was about whether sport can survive being a proxy for geopolitics.

!! The answer, as always: money wins. The match will be played. The reasons it almost wasn't will be forgotten.
